Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Negligence: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff to maintain safe premises.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion is a premises-liability slip-and-fall case that explicitly frames the store owner's obligation in terms of a duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition for invitees. The court discusses and applies Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and prior Massachusetts law, affirming that store owners must exercise reasonable care to keep premises safe, even as it modifies how notice can be shown through the mode-of-operation doctrine. Thus, it supports the general proposition that the defendant owed a duty of care to maintain safe premises.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). … Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: ‘A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if… [he] fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.’”}

Helfman v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.raw_text: Helfman v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 19 Mass. App. Ct. 553 (1985)
Helfman v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.proposition: Negligence: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff to maintain safe premises.
Helfman v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: This opinion is a child care and protection / custody case focusing on evidentiary issues (hearsay, investigator reports, hospital records) in care and protection proceedings. It does not involve premises liability, a supermarket, or any discussion of a defendant’s duty to maintain safe premises for an invitee or customer. Therefore it does not support the negligence/premises duty proposition stated.
Helfman v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 119, § 21, which governs the admission of evidence in care and protection proceedings, states that “ ‘Evidence’ shall be admissible according to the rules of the common law and the General Laws.” ... We hold, therefore, that the evidentiary safeguards applicable to the adjudicatory aspect of care and protection proceedings apply with equal force to evidence relating to parental fitness received at the dispositional phase.

Doe v. Target Corp., 62 Mass. App. Ct. 8.raw_text: Doe v. Target Corp., 62 Mass. App. Ct. 848 (2004)
Doe v. Target Corp., 62 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Negligence: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff to maintain safe premises.
Doe v. Target Corp., 62 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal appeal about evidentiary rulings (prior bad acts, impeachment, prosecutorial misconduct) in an assault and battery/disorderly conduct case. It does not involve a negligence action, premises liability, or any discussion of a defendant’s duty of care to maintain safe premises. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the cited negligence duty proposition.
Doe v. Target Corp., 62 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: The case concerns evidentiary issues: “Evidence of prior misconduct. The defendant maintains that he was denied a fair trial because the judge allowed the Commonwealth to introduce evidence of several prior bad acts that he allegedly committed against Jones.” There is no discussion of negligence or a premises owner’s duty of care.

Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F..raw_text: Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F.3d 109 (1st Cir. 2008)
Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F..proposition: Negligence: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff to maintain safe premises.
Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F..case_name: Price v. New York State Board of Elections
Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a constitutional challenge to New York’s absentee ballot rules for county party committee elections under the First Amendment. It does not involve a negligence claim, premises liability, or any discussion of a duty of care owed by a defendant to maintain safe premises. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the negligence duty proposition stated.
Morrison v. Home Depot USA, Inc., 540 F..relevant_excerpt: All “[e]lection laws will invariably impose some burden upon individual voters.” Burdick, 504 U.S. at 433, 112 S.Ct. 2059. Every provision of a state elections code, “whether it governs the registration and qualifications of voters, the selection and eligibility of candidates, or the voting process itself, inevitably affects — at least to some degree — the individual’s right to vote and his right to associate with others for political ends.” Anderson v. Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 788, 103 S.Ct. 1564, 75 L.Ed.2d 547 (1983).
